facts.text: Appeal by special leave under Art. 136 against judgment dated September 7, 1954 of Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 7, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 647 of 1952 arising out of the judgment and order dated June 7, 1952, of the Court of Sessions Judge at Ghazipur in S. T. No. 11 of 1952.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court confirmed conviction of appellant Raghubansh Lal under s. 218 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: against the Judgment of the Allahabad High Court companyfirming the companyviction of the Appellant Raghubansh Lal under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant was Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai, a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: The offence for which the appellant was tried wag, that being a Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai and thus a public servant, he framed the khasra of 1358 F in respect of plots Nos. 170 and 74/1

facts.text: Appellant framed khasra of 1358 F for plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 incorrectly with intent to cause loss to Smt. Mahura Kunwar.

anchor.surface_text: The offence for which the appellant was tried wag, that being a Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai and thus a public servant, he framed the khasra of 1358 F in respect of plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 of village Arazi Mafi Pandai, which he knew to be incorrect with intent to cause or knowing to be likely that he would thereby cause an undue loss to Smt. Mahura Kunwar.

facts.text: Mahadeo and Sahdeo, members of joint Hindu family, owned certain plots of land.

anchor.surface_text: The facts out of which this appeal has arisen are these. Two brothers, Mahadeo and Sahdeo, who were members of a joint Hindu family owned certain plots of land.

facts.text: Mahadeo died leaving widow Basera Kunwar, son Damodar Pande and daughter Mahura Kuer.

anchor.surface_text: Mahadeo died leaving a widow Basera Kunwar, a son Damodar Pande and a daughter Mahura Kuer.

facts.text: Sahdeo died leaving widow Sundra Kuer.

anchor.surface_text: Sahdeo died leaving a widow Sundra Kuer.

facts.text: Ram Sewak Pande brought suit against Basera Kunwar and Sundra Kuer for possession of Damodar Pande's property, which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Damodar Pande, one Ram Sewak Pande brought a suit against Smt. Basera Kunwar and Smt. Sundra Kuer for possession of zamindari property including sir and sayar left by Damodar Pande which was dismissed.

facts.text: On Basera Kunwar's death, Adit Pande and Ganga Pande got names mutated.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Basera Kunwar, Adit Pande son of Ram Sewak and one Ganga Pande got their names mutated in regard to this property.

facts.text: Mahura Kuar's suit for possession against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande decreed on August 1, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: Smt. Mahura Kuar then brought a suit for possession of the estate left by Smt. Basera Kunwar against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande which was decreed on August 1, 1941.

facts.text: Mahura Kuar obtained possession through court on May 31, 1943, including plots 170 and 74/1.

anchor.surface_text: On May 31, 1943, Smt. Mahura Kuar obtained possession through Court of this estate which included the two plots Nos. 170 and 74/1.

facts.text: Mahura Kuer applied to Sub-Divisional Magistrate on February 25, 1950 under s.145 CrPC against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1950, Mahura Kuer made an application to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate for taking proceedings under s. 145 of the Criminal Procedure Code against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande.

facts.text: Magistrate attached land including plots 170 and 74/1, possession given to Shubh Karan as sapurdar.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate ordered the attachment of the land including the two plots Nos. 170 and 74/1, and it is alleged that posses. sion of these two plots was given to Shubh Karan as sapurdar or custodian.

facts.text: Property under attachment from March 15, 1950 to December 18, 1950, comprising part of 1357 F and 1358 F.

anchor.surface_text: The property remained under attachment from March 15, 1950, to December 18, 1950, which would companyprise a part of 1357 F and a part of 1358 F.

facts.text: s.145 proceedings ended December 18, 1950 in favour of Mahura Kuar, possession ordered to her.

anchor.surface_text: On December 18, 1950, the proceedings taken by the Magistrate ended in favour of Mahura Kuar with the finding that her possession had been established. Adit Pande and Ganga Pande were restrained from interfering with the possession of the lady and it was ordered that the attachment should end and the possession of the plots of land in dispute be handed back to Smt. Mahura Kuer.

facts.text: Revision to District Magistrate dismissed on March 28, 1951, possession delivered in April 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The opposite party took a revision to the District Magistrate which was dismissed on March 28, 1951, and it is alleged that actual possession was delivered in April, 1951.

facts.text: Delivery of possession stayed from December 1950 to April 1951 under District Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: From December 1950 to April 1951, the delivery of possession remained stayed under the District Magistrates order.

facts.text: Mahura Kuar filed complaint on July 31, 1951 against appellant under s.218 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1951, Smt. Mahura Kuar filed the present companyplaint in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate at Ghazipur under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code against the present appellant

facts.text: Accused entered name of Adit Pande as in possession in remarks column for plots 170 and 74/1.

anchor.surface_text: she alleged that the accused who was a Patwari of the village had deliberately made wrong entries in regard to the plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 and in the remarks companyumn had entered the name of Adit Pande as being in possession

facts.text: Sessions trial: Prosecution witnesses Mahura PW1, Gouri Shankar PW2, Naresh PW3.

anchor.surface_text: The case was companymitted to the companyrt of Session where in support of the prosecution Smt. Mahura Kuer herself appeared as witness No. I and her case was supported by two other witnesses, namely, Gouri Shankar W. 2 and Naresh P.W. 3.

facts.text: Defence witnesses: Adit Pande DW1, Ram Swarup DW2.

anchor.surface_text: The accused produced in defence Adit Pande D.W. I and Ram Swarup D.W. 2.

facts.text: Accused's plea: Found Adit Pande in possession on spot, no order received, Mahura not in actual possession.

anchor.surface_text: The accuseds plea in the Sessions Court was that he had companye to know from Shubh Karan Chowkidar that Smt. Mahura Kuar had won the case under s. 145 of the Criminal Procedure Code, but in spite of the order of the Magistrate he found the possession on the spot to be of Adit Pande, that he did number act according to the order of the Magistrate because he did number receive any such order and that he did number find Smt. Mahura Kuar in whose favour the order was passed by the Magistrate to be in actual possession.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted accused, sentenced to 1 year RI and Rs.200 fine or 4 months RI default.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial companyrt found that the accused had made incorrect entries knowing them to be incorrect with intent to cause gain to Adit Pande and loss to Smt. Mahura Kuar. He, therefore, companyvicted the accused and sentenced him to one years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 200 or in default 4 months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: High Court confirmed conviction based on witnesses' statements of possession delivery in April 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyfirmed the trial companyrts decision on the ground that the delivery of possession to the companyplainant Smt. Mahura Kuar was proved by the statements of the lady herself and of Gauri Shankar and Naresh Gadaria, who had supported the statement of Mahura Kuar and had deposed that Shubh Karan sapurdar had sown barley in one field and paddy in the other and that actual physical possession was delivered to her in April 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court acquitted appellant, finding lack of proof of criminal intention.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the case it cannot be said that an offence under a. 218 has been companymitted by the appellant as in our opinion the prosecution has failed to prove the necessary criminal intention. In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, ,set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.

facts.text: Actual physical possession delivered to Mahura Kuar in April 1951.

anchor.surface_text: that actual physical possession was delivered to her in April 1951.

facts.text: Shubh Karan sapurdar not examined as witness.

anchor.surface_text: The sapurdar, Shubhkaran, himself has number been examined as a witness, may be due to the then existing dispute between Mahura Kuar and Shubhkaran as to the produce of the land in dispute for the period of his custodianship.

facts.text: Khasra entries for 1358 F: qabiz badastur (possession as before) in remarks column.

anchor.surface_text: In the remarks companyumn -and this is shown by the order of companymitment-the entry of the years 1357 F and 1358 F was qabiz badastur  possession as before .

issues.text: whether the accused knowingly framed the record in an incorrect manner

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose,, of this case, the prosecution had to prove-  1 that the accused knowingly framed the record in an incorrect manner and  2 that the accused did this with the intent to cause or with the knowledge that he would thereby cause loss or injury to the public or to Smt. Mahura Kuar.

issues.text: whether the accused did this with the intent to cause or with the knowledge that he would thereby cause loss or injury to the public or to Smt. Mahura Kuar

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose,, of this case, the prosecution had to prove-  1 that the accused knowingly framed the record in an incorrect manner and  2 that the accused did this with the intent to cause or with the knowledge that he would thereby cause loss or injury to the public or to Smt. Mahura Kuar. It is true that the High Court found that the accused knew of the litigation between Mahura Kuar and Adit Pande and in spite of this he had made an incorrect entry.

issues.text: whether the incorrect entries were made with the intent to cause or knowing it to be likely that the accused will thereby cause loss or injury to the complainant

anchor.surface_text: The question still remains whether the incorrect entries were made with the intent to cause or knowing it to be likely that the accused will thereby cause loss or injury to the complainant. It is difficult to see how any wrong entry in regard to the year 1358 F could cause any loss to the complainant.

holdings.text: The accused knowingly framed the khasra record in an incorrect manner.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court found that the accused knew of the litigation between Mahura Kuar and Adit Pande and in spite of this he had made an incorrect entry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court's finding that accused knew of litigation and still made incorrect entry.

holdings.text: Mere knowledge of incorrectness and making incorrect entry is insufficient for conviction under s.218 IPC without proof of specific intention to cause loss or injury.

anchor.surface_text: But in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect, it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code. Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory elements require both incorrect framing knowingly and specific mens rea; latter not proved by direct or sufficient circumstantial evidence.

holdings.text: Incorrect khasra entries for 1358 F were not made with intent or knowledge likely to cause loss or injury to Smt. Mahura Kuar.

anchor.surface_text: The question still remains whether the incorrect entries were made with the intent to cause or knowing it to be likely that the accused will thereby cause loss or injury to the complainant. It is difficult to see how any wrong entry in regard to the year 1358 F could cause any loss to the complainant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No apparent causal link between 1358 F entry and loss to complainant.

holdings.text: Khasra entries were not intended to create evidence for use against complainant in s.145 CrPC proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The entry could not have been intended to create evidence -for being used against the complainant in the proceedings under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code, because according to the evidence on the record the entries were made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entries made in March after s.145 decision in December 1950, so could not influence or aid those proceedings.

holdings.text: Khasra entry for 1358 F would not benefit Adit Pande under s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Section requires recording as occupant in 1356 F, not 1358 F.

holdings.text: No offence under s.218 IPC committed by the appellant due to failure to prove necessary criminal intention.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the case it cannot be said that an offence under s. 218 has been committed by the appellant as in our opinion the prosecution has failed to prove the necessary criminal intention. In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, ,set aside the order of conviction and acquit the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.218 to facts shows lack of mens rea despite incorrect entries.

justification_sets.label: Section 16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act 1951 support

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, ,set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; conviction order set aside; accused acquitted
directions: set aside the order of companyviction

edges.explanation: h2 constrains interpretation of c2 by requiring specific intention proof

anchor.surface_text: But in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect, it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code. Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention
In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, ,set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.

The question still remains whether the incorrect entries were made with the intent to cause or knowing it to be likely that the accused will thereby cause loss or injury to the complainant. It is difficult to see how any wrong entry in regard to the year 1358 F could cause any loss to the complainant.
In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, ,set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.
